creator: sctemme@covalent.net
text:
The libtool in the tarball is 1.3.4 from the FreeBSD ports collection (see 
bug 7823). This libtool is from before Darwin/MacOSX existed and can't 
deal with shared libraries on that platform. Building a statically linked 
httpd works perfectly fine, but no SO's can be built. APXS and libtool do not 
emit any warnings about this: they just silently don't build the SO file. 

CVS is not affected by this, because it sucks in the libtool installed by the 
Apple Developer Tools, which is functional save for a one line patch.

The 2.0.32 beta shipped with libtool 1.4.2, which has a quoting problem 
with zsh which is used as /bin/sh on MacOSX and doesn't function 
optimally. I have seen the best results so far with libtool 1.3.5, tweaked to 
generate flat namespace binaries.

Maybe we need to do a darwin-specific source tarball with the correct 
libtool in it.

Yeah, we need to figure out what to do with this.  This just sucks.

Note that I too am now running OS X and am using the libtool from
fink.  Have you tried that one yet?  I think they have some patches for
the issues seen with the stock libtool.  So, perhaps we can do something 
with that...
creator: jerenkrantz@apache.org
pier@betaversion.org
text:
The libtool coming with FINK sucks last time I tried it... There are several 
patches which are required to build modules as MH_BUNDLE, and when 
I tried FINK, it was still building them as MH_DYLIB...

It's now several months that I'm using a copy of GNU libtool I patched, and 
which I posted at http://www.apache.org/~pier/macosx.

And, IMHO, using FINK under OS/X is just crap, goes against all design 
principles of the OS (MacOS/X is _not_ Linux, thank God!)

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Let's make the summary a little more clear.  I believe that the workaround
described here:
http://www.apache.org/dist/httpd/patches/apply_to_2.0.35/
is functional.  But we should leave this open until a "real" fix can be found.
